column1: children;"I live in a house near the mountains. I have two brothers and one sister
column2: and I was born last. My father teaches mathematics
column3: and my mother is a nurse at a big hospital. My brothers are very smart and work hard in school. My sister is a nervous girl
column4: but she is very kind. My grandmother also lives with us. She came from Italy when I was two years old. She has grown old
column5: but she is still very strong. She cooks the best food! My family is very important to me. We do lots of things together. My brothers and I like to go on long walks in the mountains. My sister likes to cook with my grandmother. On the weekends we all play board games together. We laugh and always have a good time. I love my family very much."

column1: teenagers;"You’ve been slathering on your go-to facial moisturizer with twice-daily rigor. No matter how liberally you lotion up
column3: your skin still feels like it’s stuck in an ultra-arid desert. Sound familiar? These can be signs of dehydrated skin. For many of us
column4: dry skin can feel like a mystery that goes on unsolved no matter how many steps we add to our skin care routines. Sure
column5: there’s the seasonal element; due to drops in temperature and humidity
column6: skin has a harder time retaining moisture in colder months
column7: per the American Academy of Dermatology Association (and per pretty much anyone who’s experienced a cold winter before). In your case
column9: you get the feeling that you may not be moisturizing well or enough
column10: regardless of the season. After all
column11: what else could be causing your face to so often feel this parched? Before you panic-buy another cream or serum
column12: we asked dermatologists and other skin care experts to help us peek under the hood and understand what really causes facial skin’s moisture levels to act moody. What they told us is that persistent dryness often has a lot to do with how much (or little) hydration your skin has."

column1: adults with basic or secondary education;"On the morning of August 16
column5: left his home to go to work in Valencia
column6: Spain. He lived in the Patraix neighborhood with his wife
column7: María Jesús Moreno Cantó—known as Maje. Antonio never even started the car: he was ambushed in the building’s garage by a man who had been hiding among the vehicles. Stabbed in the chest
column8: he died at the scene. From the start
column9: police ruled out robbery as a motive—nothing had been taken. The case quickly took a dark turn
column11: with the widow Maje at its center. This real-life story of betrayal
column13: and premeditated murder inspired the new Spanish thriller A Widow’s Game (La Viuda Negra)
column14: premiering May 30 on Netflix. Here’s everything you need to know about the true crime behind the Netflix film."

column1: adults with higher education;"With the ubiquity of new information technology and media
column2: more effective and friendly methods for human computer interaction (HCI) are being developed which do not rely on traditional devices such as keyboards
column5: the ever decreasing price/performance ratio of computing coupled with recent decreases in video image acquisition cost imply that computer vision systems can be deployed in desktop and embedded systems. The rapidly expanding research in face processing is based on the premise that information about a user’s identity
column7: and intent can be extracted from images
column8: and that computers can then react accordingly
column10: by observing a person’s facial expression. In the last five years
column11: face and facial expression recognition have attracted much attention though they have been studied for more than 20 years by psychophysicists
column13: and engineers. Many research demonstrations and commercial applications have been developed from these efforts. A first step of any face processing system is detecting the locations in images where faces are present. However
column14: face detection from a single image is a challenging task because of variability in scale
column21: and lighting conditions also change the overall appearance of faces."

column1: adults learning language;"My job is a long distance from my home
column2: almost 50 miles away. I have to wake up early every morning
column3: as I’m always in a rush. There’s never enough time for a relaxed breakfast. At exactly 6:00 AM
column4: I get into my car and start the long drive. I usually like driving on the highway more than in the city. During the morning rush hour
column6: it’s not very enjoyable. The heavy traffic is a little bit annoying. So I always listen to my favorite classical music CD’s in the car – Chopin
column8: and Bach. That cheers me up a lot. The drive to work takes about one hour. Going back home in the evening after work takes even longer
column9: maybe around 70 minutes. Lately I’ve been thinking about trying to take the train to work instead of driving. That way
column10: I could still listen to my music with headphones
column11: and even read a novel at the same time."

column1: seniors;"Your grandma always remembers your birthday (gotta love grandmas!) and faithfully sends a card with a little cash tucked inside. But this year? Nada. No card. No cash. No sparkly sticker-covered envelope. Did Grandma forget? (Never!) Did it get lost in the mail? Or … did some lowlife snatch it right out of your mailbox and is now using your birthday money to buy gas station snacks? You may have been hit by a mail thief—or as they’re known in the wild
column2: porch pirates—and they’re becoming both more prolific and more bold in their crimes. In 2024
column3: more than 58 million people in the U.S. reported stolen packages
column4: adding up to a jaw-dropping $13 billion in losses. Mail theft has exploded in recent years
column5: thanks to a perfect storm of online-shopping overload and a sharp rise in check-fraud scams. It’s gotten so bad that the United States Postal Service (USPS) has been sounding the alarm. Your mail security is of paramount importance for the Postal Service
column6: and we take it very seriously
column8: a USPS spokesperson and communications specialist. Mail theft is a federal crime
column9: and the U.S. Postal Inspection Service
column10: which is the law enforcement arm of the Postal Service
column11: investigates thousands of crimes each year involving the mail."
